July 27, 2003: Fiction
THE DA VINCI CODE, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The murder of a
curator at the Louvre leads to a trail of clues found in the work of Leonardo and to
the discovery of a centuries-old secret society.
JOHNNY ANGEL, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) A woman sees visions of
her son, a teenager who recently died in a car crash on prom night.
THE LAKE HOUSE, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) Six children
living in the Rocky Mountains are forced to flee a dangerous, evil force.
WHITE DEATH, by Clive Cussler with Paul Kemprecos. (Putnam, $26.95.) While
attempting to rescue a ship full of trapped men, Kurt Austin and a colleague
uncover a sinister corporation's plot to control the world's oceans.
THE LOVELY BONES, by Alice Sebold. (Little, Brown, $21.95.) A 14-year-old girl
looks down from heaven as she describes what happens in the aftermath of her
kidnapping and murder.
THE DEVIL WEARS PRADA, by Lauren Weisberger. (Doubleday, $21.95.) A
young woman acquires a job at a fashion magazine, along with the boss from hell.
TRADING UP, by Candace Bushnell. (Hyperion, $24.95.) A lingerie model and
social climber, unhappily married to a cable television executive, becomes
entangled in movie business double-dealing.
BARE BONES, by Kathy Reichs. (Scribner, $25.) Hoping to get away on vacation,
the forensic anthropologist Temperance Brennan is summoned to identify a
shocking number of human and animal remains.
LUCIA, LUCIA, by Adriana Trigiani. (Random House, $24.95.) In New York City in
1950, the ambitious daughter of an Italian grocer from Greenwich Village
discovers the good and the bad about life uptown.
THE GUARDIAN, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $24.95.) While trying to choose
between two suitors, a young widow realizes that her life is in danger.
ISLE OF PALMS, by Dorothea Benton Frank. (Berkley, $22.95.) The adventures
of an eccentric clan in the Lowcountry of South Carolina.
THE KING OF TORTS, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) A public defender
in Washington happens upon a frightening conspiracy involving one of the largest
pharmaceutical companies in the world.
A MAN TO CALL MY OWN, by Johanna Lindsey. (Atria, $25.) In the 1870's, twin
sisters from New England become rivals for a Texas cowboy's affections.
THE DOGS OF BABEL, by Carolyn Parkhurst. (Little, Brown, $21.95.) A linguist
Non-Fiction
LIVING HISTORY, by Hillary Rodham Clinton. (Simon & Schuster, $28.) A memoir
by the junior senator from New York and former first lady.
BENJAMIN FRANKLIN, by Walter Isaacson. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) A
biography of the scientist, inventor, writer and Revolutionary statesman.
KATE REMEMBERED, by A. Scott Berg. (Putnam, $25.95.) Memories from a
writer who was a close friend of Katharine Hepburn's in the last 20 years of her
life.
TREASON, by Ann Coulter. (Crown Forum, $26.95.) The lawyer and pundit
dissects "liberal treachery from the cold war to the war on terrorism."
THE KENNEDY CURSE, by Edward Klein. (St. Martin's, $24.95.) A retelling of the
tragedies that have befallen "America's first family."
WHAT BECOMES OF THE BROKENHEARTED, by E. Lynn Harris. (Doubleday,
$22.95.) From a childhood in Arkansas to life as a best-selling author: the memoir
of a novelist.
A SHORT HISTORY OF NEARLY EVERYTHING, by Bill Bryson. (Broadway,
$27.50.) A guided tour of the sciences and what they tell us about the physical
world.
MONEYBALL, by Michael Lewis. (Norton, $24.95.) How Billy Beane, the general
manager of the Oakland Athletics, produces a successful team despite having one
of the smallest payrolls in baseball.
BEYOND BELIEF, by Elaine Pagels. (Random House, $24.95.) The author of
"The Gnostic Gospels" examines early Christianity through the Gospel of Thomas.
WHO'S YOUR CADDY? by Rick Reilly. (Doubleday, $24.95.) A sportswriter
recounts his experiences caddying for (among others) Jack Nicklaus, David Duval,
Bob Newhart and Deepak Chopra.
INVISIBLE EDEN, by Maria Flook. (Broadway, $24.95.) A novelist explores the life
and death of Christa Worthington, a former fashion writer who was murdered on
Cape Cod in January 2002.
ABSOLUTELY AMERICAN, by David Lipsky. (Houghton Mifflin, $25.) A journalist's
account of four years in the life of a cadet class at West Point.
THE TEAMMATES, by David Halberstam. (Hyperion, $22.95.) The story of a
friendship among four men who played for the Red Sox in the 1940's: Ted
Williams, Dom DiMaggio, Johnny Pesky and Bobby Doerr.
DERELICTION OF DUTY, by Robert (Buzz) Patterson. (Regnery, $27.95.) A
